intro: Pedicularis bella var. typica, commonly known as the typical beard vetch, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the family Orobanchaceae, which includes many parasitic and semi-parasitic species. The plant is characterized by its erect, hairy stems and clusters of small, spurred flowers that range in color from pink to purple. It typically grows in open, sunny habitats such as meadows and rocky slopes. Due to its ornamental value and ecological significance, it is sometimes cultivated in gardens and conservation areas.
